head.title: Is It the Degree, Or the Self-Direction?

hedline.hl1: Is It the Degree, Or the Self-Direction?

block.p: Re ''What Is Google's Secret? An Army of Ph.D.'s'' (Digital Domain, June 6), which discussed how Google recruits people with doctorates and, once they are hired, encourages them to work on problems of their own choosing:

Re ''What Is Google's Secret? An Army of Ph.D.'s'' (Digital Domain, June 6), which discussed how Google recruits people with doctorates and, once they are hired, encourages them to work on problems of their own choosing:

For true innovation, the ability of employees to select and direct their own activities is far more important than the degrees they hold. Traditional top-down decision-making is too slow in highly fluid, information-rich environments. By the time new information bubbles up to executives and they reorient their thinking and take action, the market window will have narrowed.
Self-directed employees are a formidable force. They organize people around them to make their ideas reality. Google will keep its advantage by continuing to let them use their talents fully.
